I have a very rare savage model 99B made in 1902 in .303 savage. Serial #227xx, This gun absolutely pristine. Shoots exactly to the point of aim and even have ammo and dies to go with. What makes this gun so rare is the characteristics of a 99B vs. other model 99's is full Octagonal barrel 26" long. Straight grip with a "Perch Belly" Steel rifle butt that is curved, schnoble tip knife edge dovetail. As you can tell in the pictures this gun is beautiful. This gun has never been drilled and tapped..

Model 99b's are rare and in this condition its even more rare. Model 99's used a rotary magazine to hold the cartridges. The rotating magazine uses a spring-loaded spool with grooves to hold the cartridges. It also has a counter to indicate how many shots are left. The rotating magazine design allowed the rifle to be one of the first lever-action rifles to use spitzer bullets. Previous lever-action rifles used tubular magazines, which placed cartridges of ammunition end to end. Another safety feature was that upon cocking the rifle, a small pin protrudes above the top receiver to indicate the rifle is cocked and ready to fire. This design was ahead of its time.
